element_texts.text: Completed

Sam C. Jennings
Moravia, Cayuga County
N. York
Completed

1849 March 21st Wednesday
Left home and its dear ones Monday March 19th 1849. The parting scene can be imagined, not described, & as I turned to take a last fond look, at my own dear home, and all that earth held dear, tears unbidden dimmed my eyes. Mans stern nature melted into childhood, & we journeyed on in sadness & in silence, took dinner at Dr. Whites & reached Ithica in the evening. Spent one day in Ithica (20th) making preparations for our journey across the Prairies we were all armed with rifles = revolvers = & large knives Our dress was of sheeps grey cloth, ¶ hide brimmed hats protected us from rain & sun. at first I did not think of joining the Company formed in Ithica, but, from the representations of the secretary (which afterwards proved false) I was induced to join in the evening a supper was given to us by the citizens, & Wednesday March 21st escorted by a band of music & hundreds of the citizens of Ithica, the Ithica & Auburn Compound? marched in procession to the cars?. When all were slated? we were addressed by Mr. Cushing in a very appropriate & touching manner/ and during the adress many a sun burnt cheek was wet with tears. Dr. White replied to Mr. Cushing then came the parting scene, and as the car moved on, the cheering of the multitude drowned
Completed

the low sad farewell of parting friends and our long, long journey was commenced. & many perhaps of our little band would never retrace their steps the road between Ithica & Owego is very poor & the cars were drawn by horses, the country is hilly = with excellent forests of pine. Took dinner at the Halfway House & soon after it commenced raining and snowing together, & continued all night. We reached Owego (29 miles distance) about 5 P.M. & were received with firing of cannon. There were here two Rafts & an Ark in waiting to carry us down the river, provided by Mr. Miles contractor for the transportation of the company to Independence. We found temporary shelters & straw to sleep upon, & plowed? down the river about two or three miles on account of the floating ice, & tying up, passed a very uncomfortable night, many went on shore to a pubic house, & found lodgings (22nd M) lay by today, the river being very high, called on Mr. Seneca Dennis Owego, took dinner at his house
23rd started about 6 A.M. & upon calling the roll found one of our men Mr. Kemball absent, passed between mountains either side, the river in the summer is shallow, about twenty miles from Owego we were overtaken by Mr. Kemball we gave three cheers & threw our raft near shore for him to jump on, in which he proceeded, we passed a number of little villages in the forenoon. the largest of which was Towanda
Completed

The scenery along the banks of the river is very romantic. Travelled about 65 miles, & fastened our rafts for the night, as it would have been dangerous running in the dark. about midnight we were awakened by another raft running into us, & breaking our raft apart, but they were fortunately secured again soon after the raft that run into us, was broken loose by another radt, coming down, which threw it into the current of the river, to float down & run the risk of breaking to peices on some of the numerous Islands in the darkness of the night.
March 24th (Saturday) Started early in the morning, the day was very pleasant, soon after dinner we entered the Wyoming Valley which is a very pretty valley 4 or 5 miles wide, we saw the monument erected in memory of those who fell in the savage Massacre in    in the afternoon passed the village of Wilkesbarre, we fired a salute as we passed, & were cheered by the inhabitants in return, so far there has been much boisterous merriment which was checked by a sad accident, we had floated down the river thus far, two rafts abreast. there was now a "shute" to run, through a dam about 10 ft high and a considerable fall below, and only wide enough for one raft at a time we therefore seperated our rafts, our raft taking the
Completed

lead with inexperienced hands at the oars, by much exertion we entered the raft straight, and it flew down the rapids like a frightened bird, and through the swells below.  As the swells went over our raft, some light baggage was washed overboard, but we caught it as  we passed, and saved it.  the Ark passed through next, in safety, & we waited anxiously for the remaining raft, upon which was the pilot, many of our men taking passage on this raft, thinking it safe in the pilots hands, & upon it too, was most of our luggage.  soon we hear shouting for help.  the men on the Ark pointing in the direction of the Shute we immediatley blew up an India Rubber boat on our raft & I jumped in followed by two others.  we rowed up the river as fast as we could, when the Irons for the oars came off, & we used the oars as paddles, till we reached the Art, when others jumped in and pulled for the shore, the river being so rapid, that the boat would not ascend.  soon after the raft came through broken to peices, & we heard the melancholy story of the loss of  of one of the members of the Auburn Company a Mr John Gates, by drowning, and about two Hundred Dollars worth of property (luggage),.  the pilot ran too far out in the river, and struck the outside corer of the shute and the raft commenced swinging round towards the falls, but by great exertion
Completed

it was thrown back towards the shore. when most of the men reached the shore by jumping - wading & swimming, Mr. Gates jumped in the river, as the raft broke in peices, with his rifle in one hand, & swam for the shore, & nearly reached the corner of the shute, when the current proved too strong, and drew him into the rapids, he went down, and when last seen still grasped his rifle, the broken peices of the raft were collected together a few miles below the rapids & we lay by, to repair our broken craft, Made 70 miles
25th Sunday one of our men Mr John Phelps in jumping from the broken raft, jumped on the abutment next the dam, and was obliged to stay all night, in the morning, he was rescued from his unpleasant situation by another raft. lay by today repairing our raft, & waiting for our men (rainy day)
26th Monday resumed our journey, the morning was pleasant but cold with some frost, the country rough & Mountainous with occasional Coal Mines, passed a number of small villiages & reached Northumberland at the junction of the East & West branches of the Susquehannah about (60 Miles)
5 P.M. some of our men went into the town and had some difficulty with some of the Inhabitants. Mr. Thorn? was knocked down
Completed

We were fearful that an attempt would be made in the night to cut our raft loose, & we stationed a strong guard to prevent it, & was on guard two hours, the night was very cold. Tuesday = 27th the wind blows very hard - both branches are very high, the Auburn Company refuse to proceed any farther on the raft or run the risk of loosing life & property by passing another shute. Mr. Miles, our contractor has therefore gone to Juniatta to charter a Canal Boat to take us to Pittsburgh. We visited the town, it has the appearance of a very old place, and many of the houses are built in the dutch style, Passed another cold & stormy night on board our raft
Wednesday 28th Stormy & cold. Each man his own cook, & at night wet straw to lie upon.
Thursday 29th dropped out rafts down opposite the town. Mr. Miles returned unsuccessful in engaging a boat at Juniatta, & a Coal Boat was engaged here our things Baggage was put on board & about noon we were again under weigh. the day was pleasant, the spring being a number of days in advance of the same in the lake county of the Empire State. the grass was beginning to start & the wheat crops looked well There was no convenience for cooking a few crackers and cold meat, composed our supper, & the night was passed very unpleasantly, sleeping
Completed

as best we could on Boxes = Bags = Stoves = Beams = Barrels etc. etc. & the night was quite cold. = 
About daylight of the 30th reached a small place called Benvenue 42 miles distant from Northumberland about 25? of our Company myself included boarded with a widow lady a Mrs Duncan & our accomodations today contracting strangely with our situation a few hours previous, we here found all the substantial as well as ? of the season. the Island upon which stands the alone village is called Duncan's Island we spent the day in rambling about & practicing with our rifles
31st Saturday loaded our baggage on another boat & as we moved off gave three cheers & resumed our journey, as we passed the Mansion of Mrs Duncan, she appeared at the window waving her handkercheif, she was answered by three hearty cheers, this night spent very uncomfortably as usual on Boxes Bags etc many of the men are dissatisfied with our contractors arrangements
April 1st Sunday lay by at the Villiage of Mifflin the day was pleasant with chilly wind
April 2nd Monday resumed our journey the day very pleasant, the night passed more uncomfortable than usual. The reason of my being quite unwell and having a severe headache. the night seemed tediously long
Completed

Apl 3rd Tuesday.  day passed as usual.  the canal is situated on the Banks of the Juniatta & frequently the bed of the river is used as a canal.  about noon passed some curious shaped rocks one. resembling a church steeple, another a miniature chinese wall some 20 ft high 2 or 3 ft thick and about 100 yds long. reached Holidaysburg  about 1/2 past 9 oclock in the evening went to a Public House & once more slept comfortably
4th. the Canal terminating here we took the Cars over the Alleghay Mountains. there were five inclined planes? each ?, & the Cars were drawn up by stationary engines.  the inclined planes? were from 1/2 to 1 & 1/4 miles in length.  the cars being delayed on the top of the mountain I visited a coal mine which are numerous in this neighborhood.  the coal was drawn out by steam.  our road today has been on the edge of precipices, and over ravines.  and over these mountains Canal Boats & their loads are taken, with ease & deposited in the canal on the opposite side of the mountains we was let down the mountain by stationary engines on the western side, passed through a tunnel about a quarter of a mile in length & reached Johnstown a dirty looking place in the evening & found rather poor accomodations for the night.
Apl 5th  our contractor here.  was obliged to furnish two boats in place of one the companies refusing
Completed

to proceed any farther crowded as they had been Today there was a rumour that the cholera was in Pittsburg, & along the Ohio & Mississippi Rivers upon a meeting being called Dr Morse = Dr Briggs & myself were appointed a board of health, to take such measures as should be deemed necessary to guard against the approach of the cholera. Tonight we had rather more room, but it was still very unpleasant
Apl 6th Today a musical society was formed & a few books purchased = as also a seraphine ^ the 7th? at Pittsburg = reached Pittsburg about 11 o'clock in the night. Passed the night on the boat
7th Apl had the pleasure here of hearing from home & found that the Auburn Company had anticipated the contractor in his arrangements & engaged a steamer and already started. Pittsburg is well called the Iron City, the Buildings are blackened by the coal dust & smoke from a thousand fires of mineral coal, & many that would otherwise appear beautiful look dirty & repulsive, stained as they are. the streets are many of them narrow & dirty. left Pittsburg about 11 o'clock in (the Steamer Cambria) in the evening.  the river here is about 1/4 to 1/2 mile wide = 
Sunday 8th Passed Wheeling. Had a discourse & singing, the river is at a good height for small steamers. the banks
Completed

on both sides look beautiful peach trees are in bloom & forest trees begin to leave out.
9th Apl Passed Portsmouth? & reached Cincinatti about 4 P.M. we here found the "Brooklyn" with the Auburn Company,, our steamer was about 40 hours making 500 miles. we were cheered by the Inhabitants. found a large company of Californians from Washington City, gave them three cheers, which were returned, & we here found Dr White who by mistake took another boat a Pittsburg 
Tuesday 11th after Breakfast took a stroll with Mr Jewell through the city & afterwards took the ferry boat & crossed over into Covington Kentucky where were some very pretty private buildings & residences. Cincinatti is well called the "Queen City of the West" there are some very pretty buildings & most of the streets are wide & clean below the city are many pretty country seats & extensive vinyards, we left Cincinatti about 7 o'clock in the evening
11th Passed Louisville which is quite a large city stopped here to take a pilot, to run the rapids a short distance below the city, which are somewhat dangerous our boat trembled in the rushing waters, but she passed through in safety, we had considerable sport here as on the Susquehannah in shooting at wild ducks, the boys were all so eager to have the first shot, that they would shoot 1/2 a mile, & it was seldom that game was killed by our too eager
Completed

sportsmen. 12th this morning passed the South America, a fast Boat, after a hard race, which came near ending in bloodshed. the South America finding, she would be passed, run into us, & tried to sun us aground, breaking our guard in & injuring our boat. the Capt took a gun & threatened to shoot the Pilot of South America if they ran into us again, & at the same time the deck hands stripped for a fight. Passed a pretty villiage Mt Vernon & another called Paducah,, passed also a "cave in the rock" formerly a famous retreat for robbers. the trees are here leaves out. about 9 o'clock we reached the mouth of the Ohio & entered the still muddier waters of the Mississippi. we had used the water of the Ohio for drinking, but the water now found in our tumblers at dinner looked as if taken from some mud puddle. those however whoa re acustomed to its use think it the best water in the world. on others it generally acts as a cathartic.
13th Steaming up the Mississippi with a beautiful country on either side, and with low sandy shores, arrived at St. Louis about 10 o'clock at night
14th spent the day in rambling about the city it is some place back from the river very pretty, the business part of the city is
Completed

dirty, & the streets narrow. the scourge of the human race, the cholera, is here commencing it's ravages we here furnished ourselves with a few articles necessary for our journey across the plains. reduced our personal baggage to 30 lbs per man, sending balance on a vessel round the horn.
15th (Sunday) Many shops & stores open
16th took some of our mules on board the steamer that were bought here by a committe sent in advance by the company. & about 10 o'clock in the evening left St. Louis,
17th We are now on the Missouri. the country looks beautiful the banks are in many places 30 or 40 ft high in other places low, as we go north the weather is colder and the spring less advanced. the cottonwood trees along the river are partially leaved out.
18th fine but cold morning, ice found last night as thick as window glass. passes Jefferson City about 8 o'clock there are here some pretty public buildings. the river is now very difficult to navigate there are numerous sand bars. reached Booneville about 5 P.M. the Auburn Company joined us again at St. Louis & here leave us. we gave & received three cheers & proceeded on our journey. 19th passed a place called Miami. the river banks are not much cleared. & the county not very thickly settled. saw a great many wild geese on
Completed

the sand bars & points of islands sometimes an island of an acre or two would be completely covered with them. I shot one of them with my spy glass rifle, & another member of our company shot another.
20th in the morning found our boat on a sand bar, having run on in the night. we all went ashore to lighten her and I took my gun & took a stroll in the woods, in hoped of seeing wild turkey. or some other game. saw the Michigan rose bush, soon heard the bell ring of the steamer & hurried on board. in an hour or so we ran aground again. we backed down the river 1/4 of a mile & tried a new channel. saw thousands of wild geese & shot a white swan. reached Independence landing about 9 oclock unloaded our goods & found quarters for the night in a miserable log house & slept very soundly on the floor with six or so Boots for a pillow.
21st cooked some breakfast loaded our goods & what we could on our two waggons & camped about a mile & a half from Independence in a peice of woods, owned by a Mr Smart, Independence is rather a pretty villiage. with a Plaza or public square & is the starting point of the Santa fe Caravans. we here found thousands of Californians & some Mexicans & Indians. there are some good
Completed

Plantations near independence & the ground looks rich & productive.
22nd (Sunday) took a walk. the day was pleasant the balmy air of spring was filled with the perfume of thousands of flowers = the Wild Plum Apple = & the spring beauty & violet - reminded me of the green valleys of the Empire State & the dear ones there = the birds were singing their sweetest songs as if trying to cheer the wanderer & banish from his mind all thoughts of Loneliness, & Paroquets red & Green, with other birds of almost every shade of color, were flitting amongst the dark green foliage. "Ye grand old forests." when far from the withering touch of man I love to see the gnarld & knotty trunks of Your giant trees. I love to see your might arms, & see your leafy banners waving free, in the Winds of Heaven above me, & I love too your solitude, & with my trusty rifle, I love to plunge into your gloom, & thread your dark & shady aisles, here have I passed some of the happiest hours of my Life
23rd received Letters from my own dear wife, which displayed as usual firmness & decision of character. Twas with strange feelings of joy & sadness commingled that I read these last lines from those dearer than life itself. in a few days we were to launch upon the plains, where surrounded only by savage tribes, all communication with friends in the states would be cut off & months
Completed

could pass before another letter could be received = we were on the verge of civilization in a few days a perilous journey would be commenced. perilous by reason of the multitudes going & the number of animals will doubtless perish on the desert plains & probably many lives will be lost before the snows of another winter fall. but come what will, our course is onward & the hope of meeting those left behind will cheer my spirit over many a weary mile and every day will be counted as bringing me nearer the joyful meeting. I will hope for the best & trust in him that ruleth all things.
We are now busily engaged in preparations for our journey. provisions are purchased & weighed & packed in India rubber bags,, so as to pack from 150 to 200 lbs on each mule. Pack saddles fixed - picket pins made = (from hickory roots), halters & Lariats made = fire Arms repaired little articles for personal comfort purchased. officers elected, etc, etc, the company is divided into messes of six men each. each mess doing its own cooking, and in camp we present a singular appearance. out mules are mostly young & wild, and in our attempts to break them, they often break loose & drag our boys about occasionally they wind themselves up to the trees and we are obliged to cut them loose
Completed

to save them from choking to death. We are obliged to throw most of them down, blindfold them & then put on the pack saddle, which they very often with little ceremony, land some distance from them they here fully preserve their reputation for obstinacy & notwithstanding the tax on patience they still in their varied antics, are the scource of considerable merriment. we all take turns in cooking & the exercise we have each day gives us the appetite of tigers.. & sleeping out of doors agrees with us very well. Dr Briggs slept in a house last night & caught a severe cold. I tell him he must not indulge in such luxuries that they are very hurtful to Californians, & that the ground should be the substitute for feather beds. Occasionally it is very cold towards morning, so many of the boys have to get up & warm themselves by the guard fire, but so far our company have enjoyed good health, although the destroying angel has spread his wings above us, & his fearful messenger "Asiatic Cholera" is spreading through town & camp upon his desolating way. Many are his victims, & frightful are his ravages, but we in mercy have thus far been spared.
Mr Edwin Bryant is encamped a short distance from us. I have been to his camp twice to learn of a couple of mexicans the art of packing mules
Completed

they get the fore feet of the mule in a torn page with one to stand by the side of the torn page he flounders the rope is pulled, & the torn page on his back, after a few times throwing, they torn page to stand still, we saw one, with his neck broke torn page Mr Bryant is a small man with a dark complexion & very communicative & willing to give us all the information in his power, Our arrangements being completed we commenced packing & by the 11th which was friday part of the animals were packed & moved about 5 miles, part of the company, myself included staying behind to take care of the animals remaining, in the evening it commenced raining & we had a terrible thunder shower. in the midst of which I was engaged in picketing mules, & could only see the mules by the lightnings flash. those that were tied to trees wound themselves up & we were frequently obliged to cut them loose to prevent them choking to death. after the storm was over I lay down in my wet clothes, & slept soundly till morning
12 May, the Balance of the train started, & my Horse being away, I was obliged to stay till next morning, with Dr White Dr Briggs & some others at Mr Smarts, in the morning - of the 13th May we commenced in earnest our long long
Completed

torn page horse "Paupaw" (an Indian Poney) having torn page brought back for me, by one of the torn page , it was a pleasant morning & we torn page adieu to our old camping ground & turning torn page backs upon the civilized world & its comforts, we started at a brisk pace to join our comrades ' after riding about four miles we came to their camp on the Little Blue River found them packing preparing to start we stopped to assist in packing & all started from here, in company, we soon struck the open prairie , they are not as level as I expected to see being more or less made up of ridges & valleys, with neither tree or shrub, & at this season of the year these endless plains of green look beautiful, the color being often changed by thousands of flowers, (as one or another species predominates.) to yellow, orange, Blue or crimson, we travelled from this camp about 15 miles to Harts Grove & encamped I stopped at a log house to get a last bowl of bread & milk, & did not reach camp till after dark, our mules gave us considerable trouble during the day, the packs would frequently turn & frighten the mules, when they would run & kick & scatter their packs over the prairies, & often in their fright, charge through our train and frighten 2 or three more, & we were all day fixing
Completed

the packs of runaway mules. we were all considerable tired & simply stretched a tent from the wheels of a waggon we had engauged to carry part of our baggage. till our mules became accustomed to their loads. 14 ^ did not move today in the night we had a very severe storm, the water came down in floods, & our tent not being ditched ^ around the water ran in streams. around & under us. some took shelter under the waggon, & from every side could be heard voices, as if sounding of a river calling out the depth of water where they were lying, some singing out "4 ft" some "6 ft" & others "mark under water twain"
15th a deer followed by a couple of hounds? ran through our camp this morning & our guns not being loaded, it escaped, in the afternoon I went out hunting. killed only a crow. we had been waiting here for the falling of the "Big Blue" the stream having been rendered impassable by the terrible thunder storm the night of the 14th.
16th again we are engaged in packing up to move, our mules give us considerable trouble & we already begin to throw away some of out more useless articles. tent poles, prairie stoves etc etc our mules take the responsibility of leaving some articles, without consulting our wishes there are a good many runaways = we calculated to cross the river at an upper ford, but our train got
Completed

scattered. I led my mules very well for some time when I came to a mule with the pack turned. I let my mules go & stopped to fix the pack. I then drove my mule on, & soon came to Dr Briggs's mules. we had entered now a strip of timber near the river, & the mules being tied together, they had fastened themselves to a sapling, & the pack of one had turned, soon the doctor came along , & the pack was righted. we travelled on & found our mules had many of them taken a wrong path, and we spent a good deal of ^ time in turning them back, & found some of them in the woods fastened to trees, in chasing one mule up a steep back my saddle not being fastened very tight, slipped off my horses back, & I saved myself by catching the mane & swinging myself off, after fording the river we camped as soon as possible, & found a number of our mules missing & sent back men to look for the lost animals. Most of them were found. to night I stood guard from 8 till eleven the first guard on Indian Territory. there has been much sickness among the emigrants principally cholera. our camp so far healthy. travelled today about 6 miles,, in the night ^ had a terrible thunder storm 11th? stopped on the prairie little water & no wood nearer than a mile to our camp.
17th in packing up this morning Mr Batchelder? lost one of his mules by the lariat slipping over
Completed

his head. & as I had the only horse in the mess I mounted & gave chase,, I headed him many times, but he was determined to have his own way & would run past me,, in the race we passed a six mule team. they were frightened by the sudden passing of our animals, and ran away making a large circle on the prairie, but, were finally stopped without doing any damage. after tiring my horse nearly out. I was obliged to leave the mule. and we afterwards found him with some emigrants who had caught him when they camped at night. we paid them for their trouble = travelled about 16 miles & encamped near the lone Elm a solitary old tree near a pool of water. one of mules had a leg broken & we were obliged to leave him. passed two men dying with the cholera in the pioneer train,, no wood tonight, & poor water.
18th started about 9 oclock & far as the eye can reach you see the white covers of emigrant wagons rising & falling over the swells of the distant prairies, about noon we struck the Santa Fe trail, we here left most of the emigrants travelled 22 miles & encamped near "black Jack point" we found here an Indian house with a garden fenced in & things looking very comfortable. the indian came into camp leading a fine colt three
Completed

years old. I enquired the price of the horse he said twenty five dollars. such a horse in N.Y. would be worth $100, passed a man sick with cholera after the animals were unpacked took my gun & took a stroll over the prairies. shot a sort of plover we are now in the lands of the Shawnees,
19th soon after we started there came up a thunder shower. the thunder was heavier than I ever heard before, it rumbled the discharge of cannon passed a man sick with cholera, in a tent by the road side. some of our men affected by diarrhea Every case is checked as soon as possible, passed two Indian houses at what is called Willow Spring, a spring of excellent water travelled about 20 miles. to Rock Creek encampment grass poor. and also the water. after unpacking took my pistol & in company with Mr Jewell? went about 2 miles to get brush to cook with. it was long after dark when we got back ^ & should have been lost in the darkness, but we found our way in by the camp fires lighted by two of the boys who had gone with mules after ward & returned in time to light us in ^ & I was too tired to cook supper, so I took a bite of cracker & laid down on a tent cloth slept till morning.
20th (Sunday) Travelled about 10 miles in the most severe storm of Hail rain & wind - I ever saw, the wind almost blew our animals over, and it would actually blow over ^ them animals out of the road & some of the men I believe were blown out of their saddles after a while we could not urge our animals
Completed

forward either by whipping or spurring, they would obstinately back round to the storm & brace themselves against the wind. after the storm was over, we camped near a small creek with a strip of good timber on its banks, the creek is called "one hundred & ten" as soon as my mules were unpacked, I rode along the strip of timber in search of game it soon commenced raining and I stopped under a tree till the shower was past & then went on. I soon after came where there had been a large encampment of Indians the poles for their ^ lodges tents & fires were standing & looked like a large hop? yard, soon after I saw a wolf running along the edge of an opposite ridge in the hurry of unstrapping my gun, the horse was frightened, & starting threw my gun on the ground & filled the spy glass and muzzle with dirt. I picked it out as soon as possible, & rode around the ridge in hopes of heading him. But  did not see him again, & presently heard him howl in a swamp to the right of me, this was the first time I had hears the sound. afterwards became so familiar, as scarcely to elicit a passing remark. in the night they came around our camp & serenaded us. Made 10? miles   21st in camp drying our wet clothing guns etc etc towards night took another ride in search of game, came to a
Completed

large pile of stones on the point of a ridge with a pair of elk horns places on the heap probably raised by the Indians in commemoration of some important event, returned to camp unsuccessful not seeing any game
22nd left camp early passed a good many emigrants passed three or four small streams of tolerable good water & timber, saw many skeletons of cattle that had died along the road last year probably belonged to the government, saw another wolf but did not succeed in getting a shot they are very shy encamped near a small stream with some timber. timber mostly Elms - Oaks etc saw near camp - prairie hen - Wild Onions - Indigo plant & a little bush resembling Honey locust = on our road today we saw many small patches of timber scattered around on the prairie & crossed a good many hollows where we found generally pools of water & the crossing difficult on account of the depth of the mud, in crossing one place one of the riding mules mired? the rider ^ Dr Briggs hit him with his whip, the mule sprang forward from under the rider & left him knee deep in mud ^ & with his hat now? stuck full of prairie flowers presented a comical sight We had some wild onions for supper, with fried bacon crackers & rice, we all laid down on our tent cloth, as the sky was clear & about 12 oclock was awakened by rain falling in my face  we had quite a hard thunder shower
Completed

and we all of us got wet, it cleared of cold after daylight. Travelled 27 miles on 22nd to "Pleasant Valley" some of the company did not reach camp.
23rd after daylight we built fire to dry & warm ourselves. after Breakfast packed up & started Mr Howell & Hale taken wick with the cholera. I rode with them during the day & gave them medicines & in consequence did not reach camp till after dark Travelled about 12 miles
24th the Officers thought best to move camp, although the sick were no better, & could not be moved so we left Dr White & Dr Briggs with the sick & moved six miles to Council Grove & camped on the farther side of the villiage. We passed just before reaching Council grove quite a large Indian Villiage of the Kansas or Caus?, near the road side was a recent grave and the mans horse was buried also. at council grove there are ^ a number of shops & log houses. the men are most of them employed by goverbment to work for the indians, the Indians here came into our camp in large numbers, bringing Moccasins & Lariats & Long Halters made of braided Elk or buffalo hide) Buffalo meat (dried) etc etc. they are great theives & even stole the Iron point off my picket pins. they are great beggars, & have for clothing Blankets = & breech cloths = the women wear a kind of leggins or petticoat =
Completed

26th in camp waiting for the sick
27th = Sunday = Mr Fleming quite unwell as well as Mr Horn? heard that Mr Howell & Hale were better, had a meeting & preaching in the afternoon in company with Mr Jewell? & Dr White rode back to see the sick & found them better & brought them up to our present camp, in a waggon borrowed for the purpose, when I returned found Mr Fleming worse, the medicine I gave to Mr Horn? has arrested the disease. Mr Fleming is rapidly growing worse. he has no control of the discharge from the Bowels, which resemble rice water. the vomiting is incessant, the pulse scarcely perceptible with severe cramps, & cold sweat. Medicines, have no effect & are not retained long enough. he cannot live but a short time as he is, & Dr Briggs & Dr White thought there was little chance for recovery = as last resort I mentioned to Dr White & Briggs, that Morphine might be conveyed into the system, by rubbing it into incisions & at Dr Whites request, I made upon Mr Flemings breast 100?! ^ or more small incisions with a lancet & rubbed in about six grains of Sulp Morphine, it acted as a counter Irritant, joined to the action of the morphine when taken into circulation, in a short time the disease was arrested, there are a number of quite unwell today, I felt quite unwell having been up in the night, with Mr Fleming, & getting chilled through
Completed

the nights are very cold, & the middle of the torn page very warm, we here purchased a waggon for our sick?
28th travelled about 18 miles camped near a small stream. saw on the road wild Indigo & roses, saw a good many plover occasionally al Meadow Lark & flocks of black birds & other small birds & crows & Turkey Buzzards   29th started early passed over a higher country, saw occasionally a prairie hen or other birds and a party of men belonging to another train chased an antelope. they might as well have chased the wind. the antelope far off on the prairie seemed almost to fly. saw on our road today an abundance of beautiful flowers of different colors in many places the prairie resembled a vast flower garden composed of ^ phlox pink Lilly's etc etc  we saw a plant resembling fox-glove. as also the everlasting dock & pig weed. camped on Cottonwood Creek, as we rode up to our camp an antelope was frightened from his rich feasting ground, some of the men called it a deer after our mules were unpacked, I gathered some flowers for pressing,, then saw the sick, they were doing well but very tired = we were all very tired, & had no water on the road  travelled 30 miles = laid down on our pack saddles & slept till morning. 30th mules Backs very sore, we had a thunder shower & did not move camp, spent the time in arranging our
Completed

torn page so as to relieve our poor animals all we could? it rained hard all day & at night the Hydropathic Treatment  wet sheets to sleep in cleared off cold Towards morning with the wind in the north.   31st a cold clear morning raised camp about 11 oclock = Rumours in camp of Troubles ahead? with Camanche Utaw & Apache Tribes of Indians, heard they had killed many parties of Whites one pack, of 15 Americans with a celebrated Mountaineer "Bill Williams as Leader, & arrested? a Company of U.S. Dragoons, a number of men talk of returning I laugh at them & tell them they better return that it would be better for the company for them to do so,, Travelled one side of the Trail in hopes of finding fame, saw 8 or 10 Antelope a couple of wolves but very wild & could not get nearer than 1/2 a mile & the prarie was so level there was little chance of surprising them,, flushed 3 or 4 Prairie hens  Travelled about 26? miles & camped on Little Turkey creek saw here where the Arkansas Trail Joins The Santa-fe Trail slept on our pack Saddles, 1st clear & pleasant heard today of a Buffalo being killed by another party, all all eager to ^ see these monsters of the Plains, & in fancy we see roasting ribs
Completed

& smoking steaks = in hopes of seeing some game struck off on the Prairie,, saw fires, a couple of black spots far off on the Prairie & seen after on the Top a ridge saw seven Buffalo, they were formidable looking animals with their large heads & humps I rode up a ravine towards them as cautiously as possible till I could see their humps, then dismounted & picketted my horse,, & stooping down tried to get as close as possible for a good shot in the meantime something startled them & I was compelled to return disappointed  I did not think its prudent to chase them, knowing we should need all our animals & all their strength, for the barren plains before us.  they have a clumsy rolling gait when running, & it takes a tolerable fast horse to keep by their side, when started they keep the ^ same pace till they seem like small spots upon the distant Prairie & then disappear in the distance.  we even after saw in different herds hundreds of Buffalo & tried hard to get a shot but was unsuccessful  I found in my ride a cow that had just been killed, I came near shooting it supposing it to be alive, as the hunter that killed it only cut out a little of the meat,, I took
Completed

peice of the skin, cut out some of the meat & with Buckskin strings served it it up in the peice of skin & slinging it over the hem of my spanish Saddle carried it very comfortably to ^ the train, where I placed it on one of my pack mules though with some difficulty - as he was probably frightened by smelling the blood,  we saw all along the trail where the Buffalo had rolled in the dust & large bunches of hair were scattered around, Our Guide proposed to me to ride about six miles to a place where he thought we should find Buffalo & where we would probably Camp.  I eagerly accepted to the proposal & we started forward, we had not rode more than a mile when I saw an Antelope on our left, we dismounted, the antelope came within 200 yards sniffing the air not knowing what we were, when dropping - on one knee I gave him my ball in the centre of his forehead killing him instantly,, the Guide spoke in surprise "then I declare you have hit him" he proved to be very fat, we stopped to butcher him and divided his meat among the different members of the Company. we flushed one or
Completed

two Prairie hens in the course of the day,, Travelled 30 Miles & encamped on "Owl Creek" & with Antelope & Buffalo meat we fared better than common,, slept on the ground as usual
2nd was asked by our Captain to go in advance of the main party as a hunter & scout  we are now in the Pawnee & Comanche territory & more caution is necessary in our advance one of our men Mr Ackley lost his horse he wounded a Buffalo & brought him down he rode near him & dismounted picketed his horse & commenced reloading his fire arms, soon a herd of Buffalo came charging past within a few yds of him the horse frightened broke loose & joined as they generally do the herd of Buffalo. the wounded ^ Buffalo also jumped up & joined the company & he lost both Horse & Buffalo & was obliged to walk to camp some six or seven miles crossed some creeks in our ride today towards noon saw thousands of Buffalo, the plains far off were blackened by the almost countless herds, rode up a ravine towards a herd of Buffalo near us,, the herd began to move off as I approached, a cow waiting for its calf lingered behind the herd, so I came up with in about 200 yds
Completed

I dropped on one knee took diliberate aim but my gun missed fire, I put in fresh powder, & feeling ^ in the meantime compassion for the animal whose maternal solicitude had led it into danger & I could not (Eager as I was to kill the first Buffalo) shoot her & turned my rifle towards a surly bull some 300 or 400 yards distant. my ball struck him a little to far forward in the shoulder being so far off I heard the ball (after the report) strike against the Buffalo, it went off limping & being far from the train I did not think best to pursue it,, soon after found a calf that has been left behind my the herd. it was lying down as if trying to hide, (or frightened) & I rode up to it without any difficulty - I stopped a short time to view the miniature Buffalo & then left it unharmed.  Soon after started many herds they were n\mostly to the right of the trail & would when started cross the it generally about 4 or 500 yds in advance of the party as soon as I noticed this I rode in advance & watching the next herd ^ when it started made calculations where they would run  I rode into a ravine (as there were many
Completed

little ridges running paralell with the course of the Buffalo) & picketing my horse, waited for the coming herd. they came within a few rods? of me & as I was preparing to fire into them, my horse ^ generally very gentle hearing the herd thundering by became frightened & then getting a view of them over the low ridge seemed almost frantic & I was compelled to throw down my gun & mount so I could manage him if he broke loose, & thereby lost my chance for shooting although at the short distance the Buffalo were from me I could easily have shot one or more through the Body with my Guns as I had 4 shots besides my revolver. Crossed the Little Arkansas & camped on the main river (Arkansas) the water muddy with floating particles of Mica & unclear shallow with a sandy bottom, the river was? 12 or 15 Rods Wide = Distance travelled 27 miles = in our march today we passed through a number of Prairie dog villiages,, they are about twice the size of a common Grey Squirrell with a short tail & they would frequently sit by the side of their burrow & bark (like alittle puppy) at us as we passed,, saw animals we call Prairie squirell ^ or gopher smaller considerable than prairie dogs. our Guard tonight doubled, we are now on more dangerous ground & use greater caution in our advance  my watch was from 1 to 3 in the morning
Completed

While on guard, as the moon shone brightly, I saw, (what I supposed at first) was a body of Indians moving about as if trying to surprise us, but after watching their movements closely for some time I came to the conclusion that they were a herd of Buffalo feeding about on the Prairie = the ground our Bed the sky our covering
30 Sunday did not move today = Bathed in the Arkansas = no wood except a few small peices of drift wood = swam across the river after wood = some of our men went out & killed a Buffalo  we had some meat for supper, = quite a good many of our men are sick with Diarrhea = probably caused by drinking water from the stagnant pools on the prairie, which are ^ made very muddy by herds of Buffalo drinking & running through them, the water of the Arkansas is also very muddy & poor, & many probably eat immoderately of Buffalo meat = poor grass at our present encampment out mules look poor & faded    4th & 5  Passed pawnee rocks a large Rock composed of 20ft? sandstone a very conspicuous land mark upon the expanse of Prairie. I carved my name upon its yielding sides as many others had done before me. Buffalo are not as plenty today, perhaps they have been driven away by hostile savages
Completed

We must now read all the "Indian Signs" as the Old Trappers say & be prepared for all Emergencies & always on guard; the savage always strikes when least expected,, My passion for hunting carries me in advance of the rest, so as to be first to sight the game, before it can be disturbed by the advancing party,, My Telescopic Rifle has brought me many a good supper that I could not have procured with a common rifle. Made about 18 miles, 6th Saw fresh Indian signs, where they had been very recently,, & later in the day having ridden far in advance, I stopped upon a ridge, & while looking through my telescope in hopes of seeing game, I caught a glimpse of two savages as they passed from view over a distant ridge of prairie, our men keep in closer? order, few Buffalo today, Water very poor in pools, rode off from our trail & saw many splendid flowers some very pretty of the cactus family, felt quite unwell tonight, more than half our men sick, shot today at Buffalo on the run & wounded an antelope which however escaped, camped near a puddle of water & used Buffalo chips for fuel, but being very tired on guard the previous nights, my sleep was very sound, as we stand guard over our
Completed

camp & mules Every other night,  a watch of two or three hours duration,  we make up for lost time when we can  made 23 miles today, 7th Poor grass day very warm,, I wounded a buffalo but did did not succeed in capturing it, at a distance of sixty to ninety rods, a bull must penetrate some vital part, to bring the huge game down especially with a rifle carrying about 60 round balls to the pound. although I always used pointed or plug balls of nearly double the weight, made about 21 miles & camped near a puddle of water & used buffalo chips, again because we could find nothing as substitute, 8th Not so sultry as yesterday one mule died during the night, his back was worn raw by overpacking almost large enough to to penetrate the cavity of the chest, We also had the misfortune to break the axeltree? of our sick waggon We also met today a train from Taos bound to Independence MO & many of our company availed themselves of the opportunity this offered, of sending a message back to our far off home, telling the dear ones of our progress & welfare,, I then rode ahead with the Guide Expecting to find game but saw nothing except a large gray wolf that run out from the deserted walls of an old fort as we rode up to it, this fort was called
Completed

"Fort Mann" the walls had been built from sod? cut from the prairie & were fast tumbling down a few rude graves near showed that some who once occupied those walls were now silently & alone far from kindness & friends sleeping their last sleep, a great amount of property lay strewn around = Waggons = Fire Iron = Oc chains etc etc the indians had evidently helped themselves to such as they could use for painting? arrows etc, travelled 20 miles
Saturday 9th in camp repairing our waggon, packs etc A train passed us today bound for Taos where the say gold has also been found, but the savages are very hostile & destroy or drive off small lands they wished our party to go with them, was on guard tonight, & after my watch I was awakened from my sleep by a thunder storm & the rain falling in my face, I drew my blanket over my head, & resumed my nap, Sunday 10th we had turned out mules our with a guard to graze, when we received news that a large body of Indians were coming up from the South, from this direction we supposed they were camanches, & of course would make a fight for our scalps, we consequently drove in our mules & picketed them near the river, piled up our packs in semicircular breast work,, reprimed our guns & awaited the results = when they came near enough we could see in the moving cloud of savages, horses dragging lodge
Completed

poles, & also could distinguish with our glasses Women & children, this was then evidently no War Party, they soon came up & camped upon the opposite side of the river, & many crossed the river & came into our camp & upon being questioned said they were Arapahoes & came as friends ^ we gave them something to eat & while conversing with them by signs, I saw another dark moving mass in another direction to the west, I viewed it with my glass & made out a body of Indians a "War Party" the Arapahoes as they drew nearer pronounced them "Cheyennes",, I pointed to the Arapahoes & then toward the Cheyennes & made the motion of shaking hands, the savage nodded his head & made the same motion,, I then asked the same again & said "Camanche", instead of Cheyenne the Indian shook his head with a very decided gruset? of dissatisfaction & said "Arapahoe = Camanche = pung imitating the report of a gun = then pointing to a bullet scar through the leg he said "Camanche" = "Pung",, the War Party of indians meanwhile rode up near our camp ^ some 18 or 19 of them they were large fine specimens of the savage, all well mounted, & armed with Guns bows & arrows, & lances, Their hair was braided & hung down their backs & covered with silver plates large ones at the top, gradually growing smaller towards the bottom,, these plates had a couple of half moon shaped holes cut out near the centre in this shape image which gave a place to fasten
Completed

them by, these Indians acted very sullen & torn page out to fight the Pawnees. I tried to buy an Elk torn page braided Lariat of one of them & showed him a torn page half dollar & pointing to the lariat made sign I would exchange with him, he signified his ascent & asked for (by holding out his hand) for the money, I gave it to him & pointed to the lariat, he put the money in his pocket & very coolly shook his head. I made signs I wanted either the lariat or the money he shook his head agin very decidedly. I walked up to him out my hand in his pocket & took the money from him, he did not many any motions only smiled & looked significantly at his companion their hideously painted faces were not very handsome but soon after as they rode away to the east & the setting sun was reflected back from their arms & silver ornaments, the wild savage troop made a glittering show, was here appointed captain of our mess of six men,, some of the company talk of a division but after more mature deliberation thought best to remain as at present, our food was not well selected for such a trip we have too little flour, rice etc & too much meal beans etc & then men suffer in consequence with bowel difficulties
Monday 11th made an India Rubber bag in which to preserve flower seeds, from dampness such as I might gather on the road, saw today thousands of flowers
Completed

torn page ...ing colors being red - blue - yellow & orange. in torn page places the prairie resembled a large flower garden torn page compact were the masses of flowers. The Guide James? Herman?, & myself had ridden far in advance of our party when we came unexpectedly in sight of a large camp of Indians on the opposite bank of the river, they soon discovered us; leaped on their horses & rode at full speed toward us uncertain as to the manner we two might be received we kept quietly on our waythe savages came up at full speed almost riding on to us,, when they ^ as suddenly checked their horses, the cheif held out his hand & saying in very good English "How de do" (we shook hands) he said pointing to himself "Arapahoe - "cheif" then pointing to me he said "cheif" I shook my head & pointing towards the train now in sight I said "cheif" they then started at full speed towards the train. the indians who were still swarming towards us from the camp then headed in the same direction taken by the cheif,, we watched them with our glasses & could see through the clouds of dust that our men had halted: we then halted ourselves upon the side of a ridge, & with the lariats in our hands let our animals graze & waited the result after exchanging presents our party came on followed by the indians they rode by our sides inspecting with savage curiosity our arms & clothing etc etc
Completed

One fell in love with a figured velvet vest I wore of rather gaudy pattern, they followed us a number of miles one asked (by closing his eyes & laying his head down in his hand) and then pointing in advance) how far before we slept. I made motion "a long way" a long way" hoping they would not think of following us so far, they soon after left us, we, then soon after came to the crossing of the river ^ Arkansas by the Santa Fe Trail,, we now left the trail & followed up the north? North bank of the river towards "Bends fort?', and after leaving  the trail about two miles above camped for the night, making today about 25 miles,  Wednesday 13th game scarce, saw some meadow larks = Sand hill Cranes = Turtle doves = Ravens & Turkey Buzzards with an occasional = Prairie dog villiage = a few Antelope in the distance & perhaps 12 or 15 wolves daily. made some 23 miles & camped about 4 Oclock  14th travelled up the right bank of the Arkansas, towards noon saw the humps of some buffalo that were feeding below the banks near the river  crept up quite close before they discovered me. they ran up the bank & I should have had a good shot but my riflehaving been loaded some time failed to go off, not so however with the buffalo they were off in double quick time, soon after I saw another small herd of Buffalo in advance feeding on the side of a high ridge, as it was about noon I picketed my horse & crept towards them but not near enough to alarm them, my object was to get as near as possible until they should feed over the
Completed

the ridge when they had done so I ran as fast as I could & by the time I reached top of the ridge,, the nearest buffalo which proved to be a huge bull, was some 300 yards distant, almost at the crack of the rifle I heard the ball very plainly strike the game, I immediately laid down & reloaded & then upon going over the ridge I saw the distant herd had stopped & was looking back they were looking towards the wounded buffalo that was now ^ lying down, I went up towards him until I was convinced he could not rise, then I went towards the camp & signalled the men some 12 or 14 came up & we cut what meat we could carry from the huge animal. I was surprised at his immense size, I should judge he would weigh nearly as much as two good sized oxen, his horns were some 15 or 18 Inches apart at their base; we took peices of the hide & sewed up our meat with buckskin strings, our skin bags of course had the flesh side in. these were hung over our saddles & kept the meat from dust etc I took the tongue which I found very nice. the guide took the testicles which he seemed to consider a great delicacy. but all together we only took a very small part of the flesh, Upon inspection I found my ball had - struck him about the centre of the body & ranging? forward, had passed directly through the heart. he bled scarcely a drop externally, all internally, we travelled about ten miles father on & camped making in all about 24 miles
Completed

15th The river bottom to day sandy the grass except on the low bottom very poor Saw a good many turtle doves & in in one low marshy place some wild ducks & snipe  our mules backs are getting very sore from the pack saddles made today 22 miles, 16 Passed a train bound for Taos, heard from them that the captain of their company a Mr Kirker & another man was missing & they were searching for them supposing the Indians had killed them,, later in the day when far in advance with the guide we espied two moving objects as we neared them we supposed they were indians & the guide spoke "now if they undertake to run away lets? give chase" they did not run however, & proved to be the two missing men, they had by some mistake out travelled their company we told them where to find their company & passed on, Today Joined with Mr Philips from Wisconsin as a messmate, made about 14 miles, & camped on the river bottom under some large cotton wood trees, it looked towards evening very much like storming but it passed by,  17th Sunday had service about 10 Oclock some of the men caught some small catfish largest weighing some two or three lbs  started about 12 oclock & travelled about 18 miles = in the absence of better game shot a meadow lark for supper, camped on the prairie & with the wind blowing a gale & only a few green bushes for fuel it was next to an impossibility to build a fire for our cooking,  at last I succeeded by making a "prairie stove" as I called it of sods. This kept off the wind & I could regulate the draught with a sod for a stove door in the night was suddenly awakened by ^ having our blankets
Completed

pulled off & the whispered exclamation "Indians in Camp"  I caught my double barelled fun & sprang to my feet, expecting to meet in the darkness some prowling savages & listening for the first alarm to show where they might be, not hearing any, I moved cautiously around the outpost of the camp & came upon one of our guard a Mr Stewart,, he said the animals were alarmed & going towards them he saw two Indians jump up & run towards unclear some flags & tall coarse grass growing near our camp, as I moved towards the grass he tried to dissuade  me,, from going saying "you'll get shot." his prediction however did not prove true, for I looked through it in different directions & did not start out any Indians in some places the water was too? deep, to walk through comfortably,, after turning to camp, we concluded to double our guard the balance of the night, I volunteered as one 'till midnight & stationed myself near the outside mules lying down in the grass between them, I could then keep perfectly quiet & better see any  moving object. the mules & especially a White Mexican Mare several times pricked up their ears & snorted as though alarmed, & we did not see anything more of the savages however,  Monday 18th started about 8 oclock, the road today very sandy & dusty, with a violent wind from the South, grass dried up & poor, saw today some Prairie dogs, and antelope but did not succeed in getting a shot, stopped to noon in a low bottom, where we found some bushes & course grass, in the afternoon
Completed

We reached the "Big Timber" as it is called = a body of timber in the Arkansas bottom some 20 or more miles long   mostly cottonwood, camped about six Oclock under some large cottonwood trees in the midst of a severe hail storm, I shot today a Prairie Hen = a Prairie Dog & a large Rabbit,, I cooked for supper the Prairie Hen & Prairie Dog, but the latter tasted rather strong & unpalatable, I was awakened in the night by rain falling in my face, but covering my face up went to sleep again,  in the morning I found the wolves probably attracted by the game I had killed, had during the night entered my bed chamber, & left abundant evidences of their work all around me,, my provisions they had scattered around, & probably by several wolves pulling at the opposite ends of my raw hide lash? rope, they had torn the central or belly band past which was some three or four inches wide & made of stout sail cloth ^ double thickness nearly across,, I do not know how they could tear such stout duck? any other way, my packs were almost near enough to touch with my hand & I must have slept unusually sound. in another part of the camp they drew off a pack of bacon weighing about 100lbs a number of rods, but for some reason left it. 19th the country more hilly & in many places rocky bluffs, near the river, timber on the river bottom, stopped to noon in a low bottom, with good patches, but the country is quite barren & sandy, & game scarce, we found cactus & wild sage more abundant and saw a plant the guide called the soap plant by taking the bruised plants (which has successive layers like an onion) & rinsing in water it yeilds
Completed

a thick mucilage resembling soap suds, camped in a low bottom, it rained very hard in the night, but being very tired it did not interfere materially with my sleeping. 20th awoke with a severe headache & back ache & felt quite unwell  started about 9 oclock & about noon came in sight of "Bents? Fort" A trading post & fort built by a Mr Bent? the walls are made of sun dried brick or "Adobes" the walls are nearly square,, in the centre is an open space & against the walls on the inside are the different rooms for dwelling & store rooms, these are roofed by split rails covered with mud or clay, I suppose to prevent them from being set on fire by the indians in case of an attack, Mr Bent? was absent at St Louis, on business & only three men & some squaws & children were in the fort, heard here that the Utes & Apaches had joined together in hostility to the whites, & that a body of American troops some 400? were about 70n miles distant & had yesterday sent to the fort for a guide, camped near the fort until Saturday, we were therefore disappointed in getting a guide here. our company had meetings & after mature deliberation appointed four men = Mr Thurbur (our present guide, who would leave us here for Santa Fe) Mr Thorn & Mr Brown & myself to go to a little fortified settlement called Greenhorn, about 100 miles distant, & see if we could there engage a guide to Salt Lake City, across the mountains. Dr White the president of our company concluded to accompany us, which made five in all, the company
Completed

allowed us to select the best arms & as many revolvers as we could conveniently carry, and the morning of the 23rd started leaving the company to follow up the river where we expected to meet them ^ them again near the head waters of the arkansas. We camped about sundown on some good grass near the river ^& timber. built our fires & cooked our supper, as if we had camped for the night, after dark. we replenished our fires saddled our horses & rode away travelled 'till nine or ten Oclock then selected some sheltered ravine or clump of timber & picketing our horses, laid down to rest Dr White was quite sure he heard indians in the night and awakened us, but if any indians were searching they did not find us. The Mosquitoes here near the timber are very troublesome. 24th Sunday Started about sunrise saw a few antelope = tried one a long distance off = failed to hit it = saw some deer near the timber but they were very wild & we could not stop to hunt them, they were near the timber which is more abundant along the river, & some better grass. stopped to noon about 11 grazed our horses about two hours = caught a small bull head or catfish in the river met some waggons returning to the states, they were afraid of the Indians & told us the trappers & mountaineers at Bulla? had all left the place carrying what they could & had gone to Greenhorn & fortified themselves they were only some seven or eight in number & were in hourly expectation of an attack the stated? the indians a few days since attacked a small party of Emigrants at dawn? & run off
Completed

some 15 horses, we are rapidly nearing the base of the rocky mountains. Pikes Peak is plainly seen its top shining like silver in the morning sun, the two Spanish Peaks are to the left of us, & a high dark ridge lies in front to the west = camped again until after dark & then piled on more fuel & decamped in the darkness & travelled 'till about 9 Oclock then selected a sheltered place fastened our animals & lay down in the darkness & silence, & slept quite soundly although troubled considerable by mosquitoes made perhaps 32 miles, was awoke two or three times, noticed that the animals were quiet,, (they are better sentinels than man in dark nights) & we awoke about daylight  25th travelled about 5 miles then stopped let our horses graze, & breakfasted after starting again saw a few deer, made about 15 miles to pueblo the few log houses were deserted,, we found the river here very deep & swift owing to the melting snows upon the mountains, found a small party of whites here trying to cross the river ^ we stopped & nooned with them, & then tried to make our horses swim the river, we tried them several times before we succeeded & we all got very wet the current washed them down quite a ways & the horses had to make land where they could mine landed on an island & I had to go out & get him off  We crossed with out saddle & guns in a "dug out" made the party we moved with after we crossed, we were overtaken by a thunder storm, & altogether we were somewhat damp, we took possession of one of the
Completed

deserted houses built up a fire made us a cup of coffee partially dried our clothes,, & then resumed our journey. We were joined here by a mountaineer ^ & Indian trader a Mr Garey? who had been in many an Indian fight. I asked him if he ever killed an indian his reply was " I have shot at them many times but a little ways off & I guess I didn't miss" he had made a narrow escape a few days since while swimming his mule across the river. he swam by the mules side but the water was very swift & took the mule into an eddy, & in the swift current / meantime the mule was drowned & his vary? large mexican spurs becoming entangled in the mules tail, he was almost drowned with the mule, he made out to keep his head above water, until he drew his hunting knife from its sheath & cut himself loose,, he lost his gun & mule & says he in telling of it "I thought I was gone that time sure" he had procured another gun from the company he travelled with & we were very glad of his company, we travelled about 12 miles & took possession of a deserted log house ^ near at what was called charle's creek, we found no grass, & tied our horses outside to the logs, we carefully examined our guns and lay down to rest, I could not sleep as soundly as when out upon the open prairie,, because the logs prevented me from seeing the horses, or what was going on without,, although in case of attack they might be some protection, 26th we started early rode on until we found some grass for our animals upon
Completed

the banks of the stream when we stopped to let our animals graze & get our breakfast, we was about out of provisions having taken but a small supply, & not making as much game as we expected, sometime after we had started on our trapper freind suddenly  shipped up his mule, & started off in circles with his Eyes fixed upon the ground, as he came around I asked the cause, he pointed to the ground & said "horses tracks",, I asked him = Indians his answer was "feeding about" colts tracks too, no war party" upon ascending to higher ground, we came in sight of the horses feeding upon the prairie, the herdsman in charge of the horses, Espying us at the same time & thinking we were indians, started his horses at full speed for the stockade which was now in plain sight, two or three hoeing corn near the stockade or palisades came out with their riles to intercept us,, we rode up towards them and after the usual salutation said we thought you were indians at first sight until you rode over the hill I asked them how they told them so far off the reply was "oh Indians don't ride like mountain men" it was now about ten Oclock, there are here some half dozen houses log & Adobe & all surrounded with palisades or posts some some ten or 12 feet high & some 6 to 10 inches diameter set a few inches apart,,there are here about a half dozen trappers & one white woman a Mrs Dew?, & some half dozen Mexican & Indian women, one of the men had just killed a deer & we procured some of the meat
Completed

also some bacon & milk, the last was a great luxury, we have rode hard for the last three or four days & our horses look very much faded,, we here succeeded in procuring a guide a Mr Kinney,, a young man in appearance perhaps 35 yrs but he has ^ lived twenty years or more among the mountains, we give him in money & other things somewhere about $800 to guide us to Salt lake City, we took tea with Mr Kinney a white cloth was spread upon the floor upon which the dishes were placed we seated ourselves around on buffalo robes our bill of fare consisted of venison good biscuit & butter, fried eggs, coffee & milk, the settlers have quite a good stock of cattle hogs pigs etc Hens, dogs & raise their own corn & wheat etc they irrigate their lands by water carried in ditches & their corn some 8 or 10 inches high looked tolerable well,  we all slept out of doors on account of the "chinchas" or bed bugs which they said were very troublesome,  27th rained we started back to meet our company, reached St? Charles Creek about noon found here a large patch of wild currunts of two varieties black & yellow & two or three times the size of our common cultivated varieties. the yellow tasted some like gooseberries, the black being more astringent saw wild Flax Wild Pea  Wild Gourd, came across some young Magpies, intended drying some currants for seed but a thunder storm coming up prevented, rode through the rain & mud to the Arkansas. we had the last meal only venison without any salt we however cooked it by holding to ^ the fire on sharpened sticks & appetites made it delicious we were out torn page bread and all other provisions, & we now eat our last torn page
Completed

river  we found The Kirkers Company trying to cross & they kindly gave us some ham. this alone made our next meal & was as much too salt as the venison was too fresh, but perhaps it made one meal balance the other for seasoning, slept under a large cottonwood tree rained hard in the night but it did not awaken me. I think I am getting used to it. The Kirkers said they had tried the river and found a little gold here We succeeded after considerable trouble in swimming our horses through the river & crossed our traps etc on a raft, towards night our company came up & we were glad to see them.  29th in camp repairing packs, making a litter for the sick, as we should now have to leave our waggon. 30th started about 9 Oclock travelled up the valley of a creek called Zeempeleau? (I believe) grass poor at our noon halt? started about 2 & camped for night about 6 oclock saw a few deer but too far off for a shot grass better at night made about 25 miles, July 1st Started early saw a number of deer shot two through the body but too far back to kill them immediately & I lost them both, one I think hid in the waters off the creek  we searched through all the bushes on the banks, & he did not come out as men were watching outside, & he was very badly wounded, I very much dislike to wound animals & then have them die a lingering death, & I always try to avoid it but cannot always do so. in the first case the deer was a long way off & the wind blowing quite hard. I did calculate right on the strength of the wind to vary? my ball torn page slowed? too much. perhaps there was a lull in torn page the ball struck him about where I aimed
Completed

back of the ribs. one of our men succeeded in killing one & other were wounded. we did not find water & was obliged to travel late in the night about 10 Oclock, the night was cold as usual, the cold air settling in the valley from the snow clad peaks, but the moon & stars shone bright & lighted us on our way through the narrow valleys & over the ridges,, some  mules gave out & quite a number of men & mules did not come in till next morning at last going down? a steep rocky hill by a narrow winding path probably made by wild animals we found water in the valley below  2nd did not move today waiting for the stragglers of the night to find their way in, they would have to follow our trail, I went out with Mr Miller in search of game rode along the base of the mountains, but did not see any game, at noon while my horse was grazing I went among some sheltering pines made a writing table of a large rock & wrote up my journal to this date, there is considerable pine in patches along the sides of the mountains & in seperate groves. My search for game in the afternoon was not more successful & I came back to camp without any.  3rd arose as soon as I could see, made a hasty breakfast, saddled my horse,, & having ascertained the direction the guide intended taking. sallied out I rode up a small creek a number of miles without seeing any game the morning was cool & pleasant I came to a nice patch of grass & stopped & let my pony graze, thinking I had better wait here till the train came in sight. after waiting sometime & the train not appearing I rode upon a high ridge to obtain a better view of the surrounding country Thinking perhaps the train had passed or taken some other torn page
Completed

while looking through my glass I saw a solitary horseman in the distance riding towards me as soon as he discovered me. I saw him stop & reconoitre? me with his glass, I rode slowly towards him when he turned & rode back as if afraid. I stopped then he stopped & looked at me again, & as I rode towards him he made off. I then stopped dismounted & let my horse graze to show him I was not pursuing him, but waiting, he slowly ventured towards me until he could make out what I was with his glass & then rode up, it proved to be Mr Brown, he said I had given him quite a scare,, as he thought he was the only man that had left camp in this direction, & he supposed of course I was an Indian, we rode leisurely along stopping occasionaly for our horses to graze & watching for the train to make its appearance Mr Brown after looking through his glass was quite positive he saw them on a distant ridge some miles to the East, I looked with my glass in that direction at the dark line of objects but could not make out that then changed their position in the least & suggested that perhaps it was only bushes but he was confident & we were going to ride in that direction when we saw the head of the train appear in sight in an opposite direction & perhaps saved me from missing them & losing them altogether,, we rode on then parralell to & keeping the train in sight, they scared Antelope out of the Valley towards us Mr Brown being some 20 rods in the rear of me & nearer the Antelope dismounted and prepared to fire at the antelope which had stopped some 40 rods from him & stood gazing at him. before he could fire however the antelope ran some 20 rods farther torn page him & stopped again . he judging the distance too great
Completed

over the ridges towards the southwest, saw fresh Indian trails & could tell  by the fresh horse manure that they had passed but a short time previous,, struck sake river = saw a few Antelope = but very wild = camped in a natural meadow of Wild Oats or rye or grass resembling the same as high as our mules backs & fine & thick at the bottom, it was the best feed seen, but I dreaded camping in so good a place for Indians to surprise us, we however increased our guard for the benefit of our animals, saw for the first time immense numbers of the large black cricket = water muddy as we descend the river = bottom sandy like the Arkansas - 19th Crossed the river to the S=E= side. the guide said near here he was caught in a snow storm he had been to a trading post after sugar etc & was alone. he made himself a sage brush hut to protect him from the storm, & hoppled his animals but they wandered off in the storm, he looked a number of days for his animals& then gave them up as lost & started for the nearest post ^ (fort Bridger) with what he could carry in hopes of reaching it on foot, & while travelling came unexpectedly on ^ the trail his lost animals, he had lived several ^ (7 or 8) days on sugar along, & his joy can be imagined, he showed us where he found the stray animals & still hoppled, saw several antelope one was killed = where we nooned today; one of the boys killed a monstrous Rattlesnake, day very warm travelled 'till 9 Oclock before finding grass to camp upon  - on guard from 2 'till 4 Oclock  = aroused the camp at 1/2 past torn page baked bread made some very good; Mr S Jackson taken torn page in the night, camp moved 8 or 9 miles, when
Completed

we had to wait for the litter to come up with the sick, shot a sage hen & = caught a young Rabbit & let it go again = camped in good grass = rained some in the night; & quite hard as we were packing in the morning, of 21st travelled fast = proved to be a rainy day = road in many places very difficult through ravines & up & down very steep hills in several cases the packs slipped entirely off ^ our mules & rolled down the steep hills, & we had to lead our mules down,, repack & climb up again, = travelled about 15 or 16 miles and camped about 10, the litter did not reach camp until 3 or 4, the sick man had to leave the litter & ride on a saddle over the steeped places, caught here a kind of fish resembling a lake herring, 22nd started early struck across the ridge, towards "Browns hole" on green river the snake river here enters a canyon & we left it & travelled over a very broken country,, over rocky ridges as steep as the mules could climb & then actually sliding in many places down the opposite side then again crossing deep ravines cut out of the sand from 5 to 100 ft deep on the ridges we passed clumps ^ of cedars 15 or 20 ft high & some ^ were 2 ft diameter at the base the wild sage bushes interfered very much with our travelling we were obliged to force our way through them, the country here looks as if swept with a flood perhaps some stream has been damed up & cut a passage through the country more rocky than we have before seen, in many places the rocks overhanging our road 100 or more ft high, did not find a place for nooning & pushed on as fast as possible towards green river, we saw it in the distance and towards sundown struck it just above where it enters a rocky (Kenyon or Cannon)
